com.pwnetics.helper
Class CachingItemCounter<K>

java.lang.Object
  com.pwnetics.helper.ItemCounter<K>
      com.pwnetics.helper.CachingItemCounter<K>
Type Parameters:
K - the type of object being counted
public class CachingItemCounter<K>
extends ItemCounter<K>

An ItemCounter that caches values for some of the moderately computationally expensive method calls.

On the first call to a cacheable method, or whenever the counter has changed, the original expensive method will be called. Thereafter, until the counter is changed, the cached value will be returned.

While it is possible to use this class as a mutable item counter, every set(Object, int) or increment(Object) operation incurs a cache-invalidation cost. The recommended usage is to build counts using ItemCounter, then use build(ItemCounter, boolean) to produce an object of this class to analyze the counts.

Author:
romanows

Method Detail

build

public static <K> CachingItemCounter<K> build(ItemCounter<K> ic,
                                              boolean isCopyingCount)
Factory method, recommended way to create a CachingItemCounter. One can quickly build a count of items using the non-caching ItemCounter, then use this to create a CachingItemCounter with which to perform analysis.

Counts data is shared with the given ItemCounter, which can be a source of bugs. Modifications to the given item counter can cause the caching item counter to return inconsistent values. To guard against this, one can set isCopyingCount to true, which makes the caching item counter independent from the given item counter.

Parameters:
ic - ItemCounter to "convert" to a CachingItemCounter
isCopyingCount - if false, references the internal state of the given item counter; if true, will become independent of the future operations performed on the given item counter. Setting this to "true" is safest, but does incur a memory storage and copy cost.
Returns:
a new instance of a caching item counter that is either a dependent view or an independent snapshot of the given item counter

cacheAll

public void cacheAll()
Loads all cacheable values, so this is fairly computationally expensive. However, future calls to cacheable methods won't incur an initial performance hit, so long as the item counter is not modified after calling this cacheAll() method.

min

public ItemCounter.KeyValuePair min()
Description copied from class: ItemCounter
Returns the key/value pair with the lowest value (and secondarily with the "lowest" key). Not stable; if there are multiple "different" items that compare as equal (for example, if the keys don't implement Comparable), then it is possible for multiple calls to this method to return multiple answers.

Overrides:
min in class ItemCounter<K>
Returns:
key/value pair with the lowest value, or if the counter is empty

variance

public double variance()
Description copied from class: ItemCounter
Get the sample variance of all item counts in this collection. Use this variance if you desire an estimate of the variance of some population of items, of which the current ItemCounter contains only an incomplete sample. Otherwise, see ItemCounter.variancePopulation().

Overrides:
variance in class ItemCounter<K>
Returns:
the sample variance of all item counts, or zero if empty.

variancePopulation

public double variancePopulation()
Description copied from class: ItemCounter
Get the population variance of all item counts in this collection. Use this variance if you desire to know only the variance of the items in this ItemCounter, otherwise see ItemCounter.variance().

There is little difference between the sample and population variance when there are many distinct items. When there are few items, the difference is pronounced. In general, it is probably better to use the sample variance ItemCounter.variance().

Overrides:
variancePopulation in class ItemCounter<K>
Returns:
the population variance of all item counts, or zero if empty.

asUnmodifiable

public ItemCounter<K> asUnmodifiable()
Description copied from class: ItemCounter
Get a view of this as an unmodifiable object. Methods ItemCounter.increment(Object) and ItemCounter.set(Object, int) will throw UnsupportedOperationException if called. Note that the returned object is just a view of this modifiable ItemCounter, so it can change if the original item counter is changed.

Overrides:
asUnmodifiable in class ItemCounter<K>
Returns:
an unmodifiable version of this object
